did.abstract: This collection contains copies of outgoing business and personal correspondence on a wide variety of topics with a great many persons. Subjects include events in Philadelphia, his museum and its exhibits, Peale's hopes for the museum's acquisition by the city or state, the exhumation and exhibition of the mastodon, construction and promotion of the polygraph, agricultural concerns (including the operation of his farm Belfield), natural history, and false teeth.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This collection is also available on microfilm (Film 240). The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The main body of the Peale Collection is described briefly in American Philosophical Society "Year Book" 1945:74-77.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Charles Willson Peale was an artist and naturalist.

odd.head: Early American History Not
odd.p: These eighteen volumes of letterbooks, alongside the twenty-six volumes of diaries, provide a nearly complete picture of Charles Willson Peale’s life. The depth of their content also provides a wider view into life and culture in early American. The earliest volume, which covers the American Revolution, is scattered. The later volumes are much more complete and well-organized. The only caveat is that Rembrandt Peale mutilated some of the letters to sell autographs of Charles Willson Peale.

The letterbook collection begins when Peale is in England studying under Benjamin West, but really picks up speed in 1775, when he returns to the colonies in the midst of the imperial crisis. Many of the earliest letters show Peale’s fervent support of the Revolution, including his activity within the city suppressing dissent. The content of the later letters show Peale’s changing interests and the range of his personal connections. For instance, letters detail his attempts to acquire specimens to paint. He often makes mention of paintings he is working on or hopes to undertake. Later, with the opening of the Philadelphia Museum, Peale’s involvement as its founder and owner are documented. Other letters provide commentary on current events, some of which are addressed to prominent individuals. Not all letters are work or political related. Many discuss his family and their affairs. There are a few sketches in the letters, some of great detail.
